Package algorithms.imageProcessing.transform

Class Triangulation

java.lang.Object
algorithms.imageProcessing.transform.Triangulation
public class Triangulation extends Object
given correspondence between two images (in camera reference frame, a.k.a. calibrated coordinates) and given the intrinsic and extrinsic camera parameters, determine the real world position. useful reading: 
 http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/s17/Slides/11.4_Triangulation.pdf
 add other references here
Author:
nichole

  • Method Details

    • calculateWCSPoint

      public static Triangulation.WCSPt calculateWCSPoint(double[][] k1, double[][] r1, double[] t1, double[][] k2, double[][] r2, double[] t2, double[][] x1, double[][] x2)
      given the intrinsic and extrinsic camera matrices for 2 images and given the matching correspondence of points between the 2 images (in camera reference frame) where the correspondence are observations of the same object, calculate the real world coordinate of the object. 
       following http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/s17/Slides/11.4_Triangulation.pdf
      Parameters:
      k1 - intrinsic camera matrix for image 1 in units of pixels.
      r1 - the rotation matrix for the extrinsic camera matrix for image 1.
      t1 - the translation vector for the extrinsic camera matrix for image 1.
      k2 - intrinsic camera matrix for image 2 in units of pixels.
      r2 - the rotation matrix for the extrinsic camera matrix for image 2.
      t2 - the translation vector for the extrinsic camera matrix for image 2.
      x1 - the camera 1 set of correspondence points. format is 3 x N where N is the number of points. all points are observations of real world point X and should be in image reference frame.
      x2 - the camera 2 set of correspondence points. format is 3 x N where * N is the number of points. all points are observations of real world point X * and should be in image reference frame.
      Returns:
      the point coordinates in world coordinate reference frame

    • calculateWCSPoint

      public static Triangulation.WCSPt calculateWCSPoint(Camera.CameraParameters camera1, Camera.CameraParameters camera2, double[][] x1, double[][] x2)
      given the projection matrices and matching correspondence of points between the 2 cameras (measurements of the same object, that is, as a single 3D point is returned) calculate the real world coordinate of the observations. x1, y1 must be in image reference frame for this method. 
      
     following http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/s17/Slides/11.4_Triangulation.pdf
      Parameters:
      camera1 - camera parameters for image 1. the size is 3X4
      camera2 - camera parameters for image 2. the size is 3X4.
      x1 - the set of measurements of 1 real world point X from camera 1 in image coordinates. The corresponding measurements of the same point in camera 2 are in x2. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements. If the data are perfect, only need 1 pair of correspondence (i.e. x1[*,0] and x2[*,0]), If the data are not perfect, need more than 1 pair for best fit.
      x2 - the set of measurements of 1 real world point X from camera 2 in image coordinates. The corresponding measurements of the same point in camera 1 are in x1. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements. If the data are perfect, only need 1 pair of correspondence (i.e. x1[*,0] and x2[*,0]), If the data are not perfect, need more than 1 pair for best fit.
      Returns:
      the 3D coordinate of the point in world scene. note that the entire array can be normalized by the last element.

    • calculateWCSPoint

      public static Triangulation.WCSPt calculateWCSPoint(Camera.CameraProjection camera1, Camera.CameraProjection camera2, double[][] x1c, double[][] x2c)
      given the projection matrices and matching correspondence of points between the 2 cameras (measurements of the same object, that is, as a single 3D point is returned) calculate the real world coordinate of the observations. 
           if x1 and x2 are in camera coordinates, then Pi = [Ri | Ti] must be used.
     if x1 and x2 are in image coordinates, then Pi = Ki * [Ri | Ti] must be used.
     where Ki is intrinsic camera matrix for camera i, R is the rotation matrix for camera i, and i is
     the translation vector for camera i.
     following http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/s17/Slides/11.4_Triangulation.pdf
      Parameters:
      camera1 - camera matrix for image 1. the size is 3X4 if x1 and x2 are in camera coordinates, then P1 = [R1 | T1] must be used. if x1 and x2 are in image coordinates, then P1 = K1 * [R1 | T1] must be used.
      camera2 - camera matrix for image 2. the size is 3X4. if x1 and x2 are in camera coordinates, then P2 = [R2 | T2] must be used. if x1 and x2 are in image coordinates, then P2 = K2 * [R2 | T2] must be used.
      x1c - the set of measurements of 1 real world point X from camera 1 in camera coordinates or image coords. The corresponding measurements of the same point in camera 2 are in x2. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements. If the data are perfect, only need 1 pair of correspondence (i.e. x1[*,0] and x2[*,0]), If the data are not perfect, need more than 1 pair for best fit.
      x2c - the set of measurements of 1 real world point X from camera 2 in camera coordinates or image coords. The corresponding measurements of the same point in camera 1 are in x1. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements. If the data are perfect, only need 1 pair of correspondence (i.e. x1[*,0] and x2[*,0]), If the data are not perfect, need more than 1 pair for best fit.
      Returns:
      the 3D coordinate of the point in world scene. note that the entire array can be normalized by the last element.

    • calculateWCSPoint

      public static Triangulation.WCSPt calculateWCSPoint(double[][] camera1, double[][] camera2, double[][] x1c, double[][] x2c)
      given the projection matrices and matching correspondence of points between the 2 cameras (measurements of the same object, that is, as a single 3D point is returned) calculate the real world coordinate of the observations. 
                 if x1 and x2 are in camera coordinates, then Pi = [Ri | Ti] must be used.
           if x1 and x2 are in image coordinates, then Pi = Ki * [Ri | Ti] must be used.
           where Ki is intrinsic camera matrix for camera i, R is the rotation matrix for camera i, and i is
           the translation vector for camera i.
      following http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/s17/Slides/11.4_Triangulation.pdf
      Parameters:
      camera1 - camera matrix for image 1. the size is 3X4 if x1 and x2 are in camera coordinates, then P1 = [R1 | T1] must be used. if x1 and x2 are in image coordinates, then P1 = K1 * [R1 | T1] must be used.
      camera2 - camera matrix for image 2. the size is 3X4. if x1 and x2 are in camera coordinates, then P2 = [R2 | T2] must be used. if x1 and x2 are in image coordinates, then P2 = K2 * [R2 | T2] must be used.
      x1c - the set of measurements of 1 real world point X from camera 1 in camera coordinates or image coords. The corresponding measurements of the same point in camera 2 are in x2. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements. If the data are perfect, only need 1 pair of correspondence (i.e. x1[*,0] and x2[*,0]), If the data are not perfect, need more than 1 pair for best fit.
      x2c - the set of measurements of 1 real world point X from camera 2 in camera coordinates or image coords. The corresponding measurements of the same point in camera 1 are in x1. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements. If the data are perfect, only need 1 pair of correspondence (i.e. x1[*,0] and x2[*,0]), If the data are not perfect, need more than 1 pair for best fit.
      Returns:
      the 3D coordinate of the point in world scene. note that the entire array can be normalized by the last element.

    • calculateWCSPoint

      public static Triangulation.WCSPt calculateWCSPoint(Map<Integer,Integer> imageToCameraIndexMap, List<Camera.CameraProjection> cameras, double[][] x)
      for a feature, given image coordinates of the features, camera matrices, and a map from image coordinate index to camera, calculate the location of the point in 3D WCS.
      Parameters:
      imageToCameraIndexMap - a map from xs index to camera matrix index
      cameras - the camera matrices
      x - a 3 x n matrix of image coordinates of a point in n images.
      Returns:
